qas.question: Along with Dante and Boccaccio, who was a notable Italian author of the 14th century?
Who was a notable female French author of this period?
In what language was most religious literature of this period written?
Along with Johannes Tauler, who was a prominent German mystic of this period?

context: The publication of vernacular literature increased, with Dante (d. 1321), <a0_0>Petrarch<a0_0/> (d. 1374) and Giovanni Boccaccio (d. 1375) in 14th-century Italy, Geoffrey Chaucer (d. <a1_0>1400<a1_0/>) and William Langland (d. c. 1386) in England, and François Villon (d. 1464) and <a2_0>Christine de Pizan<a2_0/> (d. c. 1430) in France. Much literature remained religious in character, and although a great deal of it continued to be written in <a3_0>Latin<a3_0/>, a new demand developed for saints' lives and other devotional tracts in the vernacular languages. This was fed by the growth of the Devotio Moderna movement, most prominently in the formation of the Brethren of the Common Life, but also in the works of German mystics such as <a4_0>Meister Eckhart<a4_0/> and Johannes Tauler (d. 1361). Theatre also developed in the guise of miracle plays put on by the Church. At the end of the period, the development of the printing press in about 1450 led to the establishment of publishing houses throughout Europe by 1500.
